source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium alloys exposed to temperatures above 450°C in oxygencontaining atmospheres, will be subject to oxygen diffusion from the oxide layer into the metal.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: An oxygen-enriched zone is formed having a lower ductility than the metal in the initial stage

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The uptake of oxygen by the metal and the thickness of the oxygen-enriched zone were measured as a function of oxidation time and temperature.
property_name: oxygen uptake, thickness of oxygen-enriched zone

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The mechanical properties of the metal as a function of temperature and oxygen content agreed well with the observation that the formation of cracks stops when the crack end has reached a layer of reduced oxygen concentration and consequently increased ductility.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The use of zirconium alloys in nuclear engineering was initially restricted to water-cooled reactors, that is, to temperatures below 350°C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: interest also turned to the use of zirconium alloys in CO2-cooled reactors at temperatures above 350 and up to 600°C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The oxidation of zirconium and its alloys at temperatures above about 400°C is characterized not only by the formation of an oxide layer, which is already observed at lower temperatures, but also by the diffusion of oxygen out of the oxide layer into the metal underneath this layer which can dissolve oxygen up to 6.6 weight percent

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Figure I shows an example of the distribution of the oxygen absorbed during oxidation of a zirconium alloy containing 1.6 percent copper.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The metallic zone thus enriched with oxygen has a higher hardness [13] and a lower ductility [14] than the base material.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Tests were conducted on specimens in their initial state, that is, as supplied by the manufacturer, and on specimens with increased oxygen content.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The majority of the specimens consisted of zirconium with 1.6 percent copper (1.6Cu alloy); a number of experiments were also conducted on 2.5Cu alloy and 0.5Cu-0.5Mo alloy; and zirconium-oxygen alloys were also used.
composition_raw: 1.6 percent copper; 2.5 percent copper; 0.5 percent copper, 0.5 percent molybdenum

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: At room temperature embrittlement occurs at oxygen contents higher than about 0.5 weight percent

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The strain-aging behavior of annealed Zircaloy-2 in vacuum was studied as a function of deformation temperature, integrated fast-neutron dose, and degree of cold work.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Strain aging occurred in the temperature range 200 to 500°C.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Transmission electron microscopy showed that in the temperature range 300 to 450°C, dislocations were arranged in a cell structure

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: at 500°C two-dimensional hexagonal dislocation nets were present

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Between 200 and 400°C, the strain aging was found to be due to the presence of oxygen

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: At 300°C the strain aging decreased with increasing neutron dose and increasing amounts of prior cold work

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Post-irradiation annealing experiments between 400 and 600°C increased the yield stress of the material at 300°C after irradiation at 325°C
